weka.attributeSelection
Class PSOSearch

java.lang.Object
  weka.attributeSelection.ASSearch
      weka.attributeSelection.PSOSearch
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, weka.attributeSelection.StartSetHandler, weka.core.OptionHandler, weka.core.RevisionHandler, weka.core.TechnicalInformationHandler
public class PSOSearch
extends weka.attributeSelection.ASSearch
implements weka.attributeSelection.StartSetHandler, weka.core.OptionHandler, weka.core.TechnicalInformationHandler

PSOSearch explores the attribute space using the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm.

For more information see:

Moraglio, A., Di Chio, C., and Poli, R.
Geometric Particle Swarm Optimisation.
EuroGP 2007, LNCS 445, pp. 125-135.

For an application to gene expression data classification, see:

García-Nieto, J.M., Alba, E., Jourdan, L., and Talbi, E.-G.
Sensitivity and specificity based multiobjective approach for feature selection: Application to cancer diagnosis.
Information Processing Letters, 109(16):887-896, July 2009.

IMPORTANT: To ensure the correct behavior of PSOSearch it is mandatory for the class attribute to be the last one in the ARFF file.

BibTeX: 

 @INPROCEEDINGS{moraglio2007,
        author       = {Moraglio, A. and Di Chio, C. and Poli, R.},
        title        = {Geometric particle swarm optimisation},
        booktitle    = {Proceedings of the 10th European conference on Genetic programming},
        series       = {EuroGP'07},
        year         = {2007},
        pages        = {125-136},
        publisher    = {Springer-Verlag},
        address      = {Berlin, Heidelberg}
  }
 
 @ARTICLE{nieto2009,
        author       = {García-Nieto, J.M. and Alba, E. and Jourdan, L. and Talbi, E.-G.},
        title        = {Sensitivity and specificity based multiobjective approach for feature selection: Application to cancer diagnosis},
        journal      = {Information Processing Letters},
        year         = {2009},
        volume       = {109},
        number       = {16},
        pages        = {887-896},
        month        = {July},
  }

Valid options are: 

 -N 
 The number of particles in the swarm.
 (default = 20)
 -I 
 The number of iterations to perform.
 (default = 20)
 -T 
 The type of mutation to be applied: 
 0 = bit-flip (default), 1 = bit-off
 -M 
 The probability of mutation.
 (default = 0.01)
 -A 
 The inertia weight in 3PBMCX.
 (default = 0.33)
 -B 
 The social weight in 3PBMCX.
 (default = 0.33)
 -C 
 The individual weight in 3PBMCX.
 (default = 0.34)
 -P 
  Specify a starting set of attributes.
  Eg. 1,3,5-7.If supplied, the starting set becomes
  one member of the initial random population.
 -R 
  Set frequency of reports.
  e.g, setting the value to 5 will 
  report every 5 iterations
  (default = number of generations)
 -S 
  Set the random number seed.
  (default = 1)
 -L 
  Set the log file location.
  Log file just keeps track of the best fitness
  found through all the iterations.
  (default = null)

Author:
Sebastian Luna Valero
See Also:

search

public int[] search(weka.attributeSelection.ASEvaluation ASEval,
                    weka.core.Instances data)
             throws java.lang.Exception
Searches the attribute subset space using the PSO algorithm.

Specified by:
search in class weka.attributeSelection.ASSearch
Parameters:
ASEval - the attribute evaluator to guide the search
data - the training instances.
Returns:
an array (not necessarily ordered) of selected attribute indexes
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if the search can't be completed

setOptions

public void setOptions(java.lang.String[] options)
                throws java.lang.Exception
Parses a given list of options.

Valid options are: 

 -N <swarm size>
 The number of particles in the swarm.
 (default = 20)
 -I <iterations>
 The number of iterations to perform.
 (default = 20)
 -T <mutation type>
 The type of mutation to be applied:
 0 = bit-flip (default), 1 = bit-off.
 -M <mutation probability>
 The probability of mutation.
 (default = 0.01)
 -A <intertia weight>
 The inertia weight in 3PBMCX.
 (default = 0.33)
 -B <social weight>
 The social weight in 3PBMCX.
 (default = 0.33)
 -C <individual weight>
 The individual weight in 3PBMCX.
 (default = 0.34)
 IMPORTANT CONSTRAINT: <inertia weight> + <social weight> + <individual weight> = 1
 and all these weights should be greater than or equal to zero!
 -P <start set>
  Specify a starting set of attributes.
  Eg. 1,3,5-7.If supplied, the starting set becomes
  one member of the initial random population.
 -R <report frequency>
  Set frequency of reports.
  e.g, setting the value to 5 will 
  report every 5 iterations
  (default = number of generations)
 -S <seed>
  Set the random number seed.
  (default = 1)
 -L <log file name>
  Set the log file location.
  Log file just keeps track of the best fitness
  found through all the iterations.
  (default = null)

Specified by:
setOptions in interface weka.core.OptionHandler
Parameters:
options - the list of options as an array of strings
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if an option is not supported

getOptions in interface weka.core.OptionHandler

setStartSet

public void setStartSet(java.lang.String startSet)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
Sets a starting set of attributes for the search. It is the search method's responsibility to report this start set (if any) in its toString() method.

Specified by:
setStartSet in interface weka.attributeSelection.StartSetHandler
Parameters:
startSet - a string containing a list of attributes (and or ranges), eg. 1,2,6,10-15.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if start set can't be set.
